Explosions lead to house fire in Vancouver (Photo)
detail: <p>Vancouver Fire responded to a structure fire at 10008 NE 53rd Ave just after 8 am this morning, October 23rd.&nbsp; Several callers stated they heard explosions followed by large amounts of black smoke and flames.&nbsp; First arriving crews found heavy fire involvement in the garage and rooms above it as well as 2 vehicles parked in the driveway.&nbsp; Firefighters began extinguishing the wall of flames from the exterior prior to moving inside to search the 2 story home and continue fire suppression.&nbsp; Two residents were displaced following the tragic event.&nbsp; Fortunately, no human or pet lives were lost or injured.&nbsp; Six Vancouver Fire companies were also assisted by Fire District 6. &nbsp;Clark Country Fire Marshals are investigating the cause.</p>

Oregon Employment Department Announces Intent to Award Contract for Workforce Modernization Project (Photo)
detail:
<p><img alt="Picture 3, Picture" src="data:image/png;base64," style="height:61px; width:237px" /></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE</strong><br />
Oct. 31, 2025</p>

<p>Media Contact: <a href="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov"><strong>communications@employ.oregon.gov</strong></a></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size:18px"><strong><em>Oregon Employment Department Announces Intent to Award Contract for Workforce Modernization Project</em></strong></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Salem, Ore.&nbsp;— The Oregon Employment Department (OED), in partnership with the Department of Administrative Services State Procurement Services (DAS-SPS), is excited to announce its Notice of Intent to Award to Career Team Enterprises, a major milestone in the Workforce Modernization Project. Career Team Enterprises is the top-ranking candidate that will develop the modernized technical solution to support both state employment services and federal workforce programs in Oregon.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Workforce Modernization Project is a multi-year, system-wide initiative that involves multiple agencies and community partners. &nbsp;The project goes beyond technology. OED’s Modernization Division has spent significant time gathering input from customers, staff, and partners to understand what is working and what is not. This feedback is shaping both the technical solution and also the business processes that it supports. The goal is to create a modern, user-friendly experience that meets the needs of all Oregonians and strengthens the entire workforce ecosystem.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>This intent to award is an important step toward delivering better, faster, and more accessible services to Oregonians. The new system will focus on the customers – helping job seekers, employers, and workforce partners by making it easier to connect with the tools and support they need. It will also improve how OED staff work behind the scenes, enabling more efficient and responsive service delivery.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>“We are thrilled to reach this point in the project,” said Andrew R. Stolfi, Employment Department Director. “This progress reflects the dedication and hard work of our team, as well as the invaluable support from our workforce partners and local workforce boards. Together, we’re building a system that works better for everyone.”</p>

<p>While the final contract has not yet been signed, the Notice of Intent to Award (NITA) marks the end of the procurement evaluation phase and the beginning of contract negotiations.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Learn more about the Workforce Modernization Project at <a href="https://www.oregon.gov/employ/Agency/Pages/Learn-About-Modernization.aspx">the OED website</a>.</p>

<div>
<p style="text-align: center;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: center;">###</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
</div>

<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>About the Oregon Employment Department </strong></p>

<p>The Oregon Employment Department (OED) provides economic stability to Oregon communities by providing vital services to both businesses and workers. &nbsp;OED supports businesses with finding qualified job candidates, labor market information, tax incentives and support, and retaining talent through economic downturns. OED promotes employment through wage replacement benefits during unemployment and significant life events, job placement, training, and useful career information. Learn more at <a href="https://www.oregon.gov/employ/Pages/default.aspx">employment.oregon.gov.</a></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>About Workforce Operations</strong></p>

<p>OED’s Workforce Operations division is a partner in WorkSource Oregon, a consortium of state agencies and local workforce boards, and it operates 37 WorkSource Oregon centers across the state. WorkSource Oregon offers a wide range of free services, including personalized career coaching, resume writing, interview practice, and job search strategies. For employers and businesses, WorkSource Oregon provides support for job postings and finding qualified candidates, hiring incentives, and access to labor-market data – all at no cost. Visit <a href="https://www.worksourceoregon.org/">worksourceoregon.org</a> for more information.</p>

<div>
<hr />
<p>&nbsp;</p>
</div>

<p>The Oregon Employment Department (OED) is an equal opportunity agency. OED provides free help so you can use our services. Some examples are sign language and spoken language interpreters, written materials in other languages, large print, audio, and other formats. To get help, please call 503-947-1444. TTY users call 711. You can also send an email to <a href="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.govc">communications@employ.oregon.gov</a>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>El Departamento de Empleo de Oregon (OED) es una agencia de igualdad de oportunidades. El OED proporciona ayuda gratuita para que usted pueda utilizar nuestros servicios. Algunos ejemplos son intérpretes de lengua de señas e idiomas hablados, materiales escritos en otros idiomas, letra grande, audio y otros formatos. Para obtener ayuda, por favor llame al 503-947-1444. Usuarios de TTY pueden llamar al 711. También puede enviar un correo electrónico a <a href="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov">communications@employ.oregon.gov</a>.</p>

Oregon Legislators Recognized as Public Health Champions as 2025 Session Fails to Fund Critical Health Investments (Photo)
detail:
<h1 dir="ltr"><img alt="Text

Description automatically generated with low confidence" src="data:image/png;base64," style="height:146.99600472397418; margin-left:-18.486505270473764px; margin-top:0px; width:776.0917409938608" /><span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif; font-size:23pt">FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE</span></h1>

<p dir="ltr"><strong>Contact:</strong><br />
<span style="font-size:11pt">Allison Mora, Public Health Program Manager</span><br />
<span style="font-size:11pt">Coalition of Local Health Officials</span><br />
<span style="font-size:11pt">971-480-0752</span><br />
<span style="font-size:11pt">allison@oregonclho.org</span></p>

<h2 dir="ltr"><span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif; font-size:17pt">Oregon Legislators Recognized as Public Health Champions as 2025 Session Fails to Fund Critical Health Investments</span></h2>

<h3 dir="ltr"><span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif; font-size:13pt">CLHO Releases Legislative Scorecard Highlighting Leadership While Calling on Governor, Legislative Leaders to Prioritize Public Health Funding</span></h3>

<p dir="ltr"><strong>PORTLAND, OR – November 3rd, 2025</strong><span style="font-size:11pt"> – Despite advancing its most ambitious public health agenda to date, the Coalition of Local Health Officials (CLHO) announced today that no new investments in Oregon's public health system were made during the 2025 legislative session. The organization's Legislative Scorecard recognizes lawmakers who championed public health priorities while highlighting the urgent need for future funding to support the state's underfunded public health infrastructure.</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">"The 2025 legislative session was a difficult one," said Sarah Lochner, CLHO Executive Director. "Economic uncertainty drove down Oregon's revenue forecast, leaving the Legislature with tough choices to make. But year after year, public health gets pushed aside—and Oregon's communities pay the price."</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">CLHO advanced a comprehensive public health agenda this session, advocating for investments in Public Health Modernization, the public health workforce, addiction primary prevention, and maternal and child health, along with stronger policies for synthetic nicotine regulation and taxation. But many proposals stalled in the Joint Committee on Ways and Means and never came to a full chamber vote, leaving Oregon's public health system underfunded yet again.</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">As a result, many legislators earned a 0% on this year's scorecard—not because they opposed public health, but because the Legislature failed to act on key bills that would have strengthened Oregon's health infrastructure.</span></p>

<h3 dir="ltr"><span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif; font-size:13pt">Recognizing 2025 Public Health Champions</span></h3>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Despite the challenging session, several legislators demonstrated exceptional leadership on public health priorities, earning recognition as Public Health Champions, Rising Stars, and members of the Public Health Honor Roll.</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><strong>Public Health Champions</strong><span style="font-size:11pt">: Legislators who went above and beyond to advance public health this session, earning the highest tier of recognition on our scorecard. These champions also earned extra credit by repeatedly stepping up for public health.</span></p>

<ul>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Rep. Rob Nosse – 143%</strong></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Rep. Hai Pham – 143%</strong></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Rep. Travis Nelson – 129%</strong></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Sen. Deb Patterson – 117%</strong></p>
     </li>
</ul>

<p dir="ltr"><strong>Public Health Rising Stars: </strong><span style="font-size:11pt">Senators who demonstrated strong support for public health and the CLHO agenda, earning 100% and the second tier of recognition on this year's scorecard.</span></p>

<ul>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Sen. Courtney Neron Misslin – 100%</strong></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Sen. Floyd Prozanski – 100%</strong></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Sen. James Manning, Jr. – 100%</strong></p>
     </li>
</ul>

<p dir="ltr"><strong>Public Health Honor Roll</strong><span style="font-size:11pt">: Legislators who stepped up, many for the first time, to support CLHO's top priorities and demonstrated a clear commitment to protecting and strengthening Oregon's public health system, scoring 100%.</span></p>

<ul>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Tom Andersen</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Willy Chotzen</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Lisa Fragala</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Mark Gamba</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Shannon Isadore</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Lesly Munoz</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Hoa Nguyen</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Sue Rieke Smith</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Rep. Jules Walters</span></p>
     </li>
</ul>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">"We are grateful to the champions, rising stars, and others who stood up for public health during the 2025 session," Lochner said. "These legislators understand that a strong public health system isn't a luxury—it's the foundation of healthy communities and a thriving economy."</span></p>

<h3 dir="ltr"><span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif; font-size:13pt">What Was at Stake</span></h3>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">The scorecard focused on five of CLHO’s top legislative priorities, which included:</span></p>

<ul>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>HB 3916 – Public Health Workforce Package</strong><span style="font-size:11pt">: Addressing critical staffing shortages in local health departments across Oregon</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>HB 2954 – Addiction Primary Prevention</strong><span style="font-size:11pt">: Investing in primary prevention programs to stop substance use before it starts</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>HB 2528 – Synthetic Nicotine Regulation</strong><span style="font-size:11pt">: Strengthening protections for youth against unregulated and emerging nicotine products</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Public Health Modernization Funding</strong><span style="font-size:11pt">: Building a stronger, more flexible statewide public health system</span></p>
     </li>
     <li dir="ltr">
     <p dir="ltr"><strong>Maternal and Child Health Investments</strong><span style="font-size:11pt">: Supporting healthy pregnancies and early childhood development</span></p>
     </li>
</ul>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">Without these investments, Oregon's local health departments continue to operate with limited resources, understaffed teams, and reduced capacity to respond to emerging health threats.</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">&nbsp;“Flat funding is actually a funding decrease,” Lochner emphasized. “Rising staff costs mean the funding we have buys less this year than it did last year—so even maintaining current service levels becomes impossible.”</span></p>

<h3 dir="ltr"><span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif; font-size:13pt">Call to Action</span></h3>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">CLHO is urging Governor Kotek and legislative leadership to prioritize public health in future agency budgets and legislative sessions.</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">"Oregon can't afford to keep underfunding prevention," Lochner said. "We've seen what happens when we don't invest in public health—communities suffer, health disparities grow, health insurance costs skyrocket, and we end up spending more on crisis response instead of prevention. It's time for that to change."</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">The full scorecard, including detailed methodology, is available at </span><a href="http://oregonclho.org/advocacy" style="text-decoration-line: none;"><strong>oregonclho.org/advocacy</strong></a><span style="font-size:11pt">.</span></p>

<h3 dir="ltr"><span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif; font-size:13pt">About CLHO</span></h3>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">The Coalition of Local Health Officials (CLHO) is a statewide coalition representing Oregon's local health departments and health officials. CLHO advocates for policies and resources that strengthen Oregon's public health system, promote health equity, and support the health of communities served by local health departments across the state.</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:11pt">For more information about CLHO's legislative priorities and the 2025 Legislative Scorecard, visit </span><a href="http://oregonclho.org/advocacy" style="text-decoration-line: none;"><strong>oregonclho.org/advocacy</strong></a><span style="font-size:11pt">.&nbsp;</span></p>

<p dir="ltr"><strong>###</strong></p>

<div>&nbsp;</div>
org: Oregon Coalition of Local Health Officials (CLHO)

Media Advisory: Paid Leave Oregon Invites Public Input on Proposed Administrative Rules (Photo)
detail:
<p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Nov. 10, 2025</strong></p>

<p><strong>Media Contact:</strong> <a href="mailto:Communications@employ.oregon.gov">Communications@employ.oregon.gov</a></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-size:20px">MEDIA ADVISORY</span></p>

<p style="text-align:center"><strong><em>Paid Leave Oregon Invites Public Input on Proposed Administrative Rules</em></strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Salem, Ore.</strong> – Paid Leave Oregon is proposing updates to program rules and inviting public comment.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The proposed changes help clarify how people qualify for Paid Leave Oregon benefits, how employers share information with employees, and how the program handles things like appeals, verification documents, and situations where someone is unable to manage their own claim. The updates also align the program with new state laws passed in the 2023 and 2025 legislative sessions.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The full proposed rule text as well as more information on the related public hearings is attached.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Public comment period</strong></p>

<p>The public may comment through <strong>Friday, December 5, 2025 at 11:55 p.m.</strong></p>

<p>Comments may be submitted by email to: <a href="mailto:OED_Rules@employ.oregon.gov"><strong>OED_Rules@employ.oregon.gov</strong></a></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Public hearings</strong></p>

<p>Two virtual public hearings are scheduled:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Monday, November 17, 2025</strong></p>

<ul>
     <li>1:00 – 2:30 p.m.</li>
     <li><strong><a href="https://www.zoomgov.com/webinar/register/WN_eVDfpfM6QrOEMqwDyA6J6Q">Click here to join the meeting</a></strong></li>
     <li>Phone: 1-669-254-5252</li>
     <li>Conference ID: 1604539652</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Wednesday, November 19, 2025</strong></p>

<ul>
     <li>10:00 – 11:30 a.m.</li>
     <li><strong><a href="https://www.zoomgov.com/webinar/register/WN_DOOONZjnQTWaKIlDppGyjQ">Click here to join the meeting</a></strong></li>
     <li>Phone: 1-669-254-5252</li>
     <li>Conference ID: 1604824733</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>About the rulemaking process</strong></p>

<p>Updating rules is a regular part of keeping Paid Leave Oregon efficient and accessible to Oregonians. This public comment period allows people review the proposed changes, ask questions, and provide input before rules are finalized. After the comment period closes, the Oregon Employment Department will review feedback and adopt final rules.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>If approved, the rules would take effect <strong>January 1, 2026</strong>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>More information and the full text of the proposed rules are available on the Paid Leave Oregon website.</p>

<p style="text-align:center">###</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Oregon Employment Department (OED) is an equal opportunity agency. OED provides free help so you can use our services. Some examples are sign language and spoken-language interpreters, written materials in other languages, large print, audio, and other formats. To get help, please call 503-947-1444. TTY users call 711. You can also send an email to&nbsp;<a href="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov" title="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov">communications@employ.oregon.gov</a><u>.</u></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>El Departamento de Empleo de Oregon (OED) es una agencia de igualdad de oportunidades. El OED proporciona ayuda gratuita para que usted pueda utilizar nuestros servicios. Algunos ejemplos son intérpretes de lengua de señas e idiomas hablados, materiales escritos en otros idiomas, letra grande, audio y otros formatos. Para obtener ayuda, por favor llame al 503-947-1444. Usuarios de TTY pueden llamar al 711. También puede enviar un correo electrónico a&nbsp;<a href="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov">communications@employ.oregon.gov</a><u>.</u></p>

detail: <p>On 11/12/25 at approximately 2128 hrs a witness called 911 to report finding a collision near the 26600 block of NE 182nd Ave, Battle Ground, WA.&nbsp;&nbsp; Two vehicles were involved in a collision resulting in significant injuries.&nbsp; One of the occupants succumbed to their injuries at the scene and the two other occupants were transported to the hospital.&nbsp; The Clark County Sheriff’s Office Traffic Homicide Unit was called out to conduct an investigation.&nbsp; The roadway will be closed during the investigation. This case is active pending further investigation.&nbsp;</p>

headline: Final Suspect Arrested for Murder of Liam Spahnle-Bailey
Duplex fire in Vancouver Thursday evening (Photo)
detail: <p>At 11:15 PM Thursday evening, the Vancouver Fire Department was dispatched to 1010 SE Morgan RD for a structure fire. First arriving crews found heavy smoke and fire coming from the front of the duplex. Hose lines were deployed to attack the fire and several holes were cut in the roof to release smoke and heat out of the building. It took 30 minutes to bring the fire under control after it spread to the attic. About 12 units were on scene for a total of approximately 30 firefighters. A critical safety concern was observed during the incident as an energized power line came down around the building but did not result in any injuries. One adult from the duplex was evaluated by AMR for smoke inhalation and is being evaluated at a local area hospital for non-life threatening injuries. No other injuries were reported. The Red Cross was requested to assist several adults who were displaced. The cause of the fire is under investigation by the Vancouver Fire Marshal’s Office.</p>

Unemployment Insurance tax and Paid Leave Oregon contribution rates hold steady for 2026 (Photo)
detail:
<p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE</strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />
Nov. 18, 2025</p>

<p><strong>Media Contact:&nbsp;</strong><a href="mailto:OED_Communications@employ.oregon.gov">Communications@employ.oregon.gov</a></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size:16px"><strong>Unemployment Insurance tax and Paid Leave Oregon contribution rates hold steady for 2026</strong></span><br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p>SALEM, Ore. — The Oregon Employment Department has announced that the tax schedule for Unemployment Insurance (UI) and the contribution rate for Paid Leave Oregon will not change in 2026. Oregon will remain in Tax Schedule 3 for Unemployment Insurance, and the Paid Leave Oregon contribution rate will remain at 1 percent.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>“Keeping these rates flat is important for Oregon’s economy, especially as businesses navigate increasing economic uncertainty,” Employment Director Andrew R. Stolfi said. “Both of our trust funds are healthy and stable, and we remain committed to operating these programs as efficiently as possible to minimize the impact on employers.”</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Employers can view their specific 2026 rate information in their Frances Online account.&nbsp;The department has also mailed each employer their annual notice of the new rates.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>2026 Unemployment Insurance Tax Rate</strong>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The department uses a formula established by Oregon statute to calculate the annual payroll tax rate. Most Oregon employers pay payroll taxes that go into Oregon’s Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund, which is the source of Unemployment Insurance benefits for Oregon workers. Workers do not contribute to this fund or to their unemployment benefits.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Oregon will remain in Tax Schedule 3 for 2026. The taxable wage base – the maximum amount of wages subject to Unemployment Insurance taxes – is based on the annual average wage in Oregon. OED uses a statutory formula to calculate the annual average wage, which tends to rise annually, largely due to inflation.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Following the increase in Oregon’s annual average wage, the taxable wage base will rise <strong>4.4 percent</strong> in 2026<strong>,</strong> from $54,300 per employee in 2025 to<strong> $56,700</strong>:</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
     <tbody>
          <tr>
               <td style="width:90px">
               <p>Year</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:138px">
               <p>Tax Schedule</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:198px">
               <p>Taxable Wage Base</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:120px">
               <p>% change</p>
               </td>
          </tr>
          <tr>
               <td style="width:90px">
               <p>2025</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:138px">
               <p>3</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:198px">
               <p>$54,300</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:120px">
               <p>--</p>
               </td>
          </tr>
          <tr>
               <td style="width:90px">
               <p>2026</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:138px">
               <p>3</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:198px">
               <p>$56,700</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:120px">
               <p>+4.4%</p>
               </td>
          </tr>
     </tbody>
</table>

<div style="clear:both;">&nbsp;</div>

<p>For new employers (those with less than 12 months of reported payroll), the Unemployment Insurance payroll base tax rate will remain at<strong> 2.4%</strong> for 2026.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>“The fact that we are able to keep the same tax schedule next year, even as the unemployment rate has been rising slowly, is a testament to how well Oregon’s system works compared to other states,” Stolfi added. “As a self-balancing fund, Oregon’s Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund is one of the healthiest in the country.”</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The goal of the statutory formula is to reach a balance between revenue and expenditures, where the state takes in about the same amount of money in taxes as it pays out in Unemployment Insurance benefits. The trust fund balance also earns interest, which helps keep employers’ tax rates lower.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>2026 Paid Leave Oregon Contribution Rate</strong>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Paid Leave Oregon contribution rate for 2026 will remain at 1%. The four-year-old trust fund continues to cover benefits as well as the administrative costs to run the program.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Both employers and employees pay contributions to the Paid Leave Oregon Trust Fund, which provides benefits for Oregon workers.&nbsp;Employees pay 60 percent of the rate and employers (with 25 employees or more) pay 40 percent.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The level of subject wages for Paid Leave Oregon contributions, set by the annual <a href="https://www.ssa.gov/oact/cola/cbb.html">Social Security taxable maximum wage</a> amount, will rise 4.7 percent to $184,500 of wages per employee in 2026, also generally due to inflation.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
     <tbody>
          <tr>
               <td style="width:114px">
               <p>Year</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:168px">
               <p>Contribution Rate</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:234px">
               <p>Taxable Maximum Wage</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:108px">
               <p>% change</p>
               </td>
          </tr>
          <tr>
               <td style="width:114px">
               <p>2025</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:168px">
               <p>1%</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:234px">
               <p>$176,100</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:108px">
               <p>--</p>
               </td>
          </tr>
          <tr>
               <td style="width:114px">
               <p>2026</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:168px">
               <p>1%</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:234px">
               <p>$184,500</p>
               </td>
               <td style="width:108px">
               <p>+4.7%</p>
               </td>
          </tr>
     </tbody>
</table>

<div style="clear:both;">&nbsp;</div>

<p>“Local businesses are the heart of Oregon’s economy, so we want to make it as easy as possible to manage their payroll reporting and employee benefit requests,” Stolfi said. “We are here to help employers through every step of this important process.”</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The overall UI tax and Paid Leave Contribution rates for 2025 and 2026 are posted on the Employment Department website at <a href="https://www.oregon.gov/employ/Businesses/Pages/Current-Tax-Rate.aspx">employers.oregon.gov</a>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: center;">###&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>About Unemployment Insurance</strong></p>

<p>Oregon’s Unemployment Insurance Program supports people and communities when facing economic uncertainty. For those who are unemployed through no fault of their own, the temporary, partial wage replacement offers financial security while seeking new work. Benefit payments also soften the local economic shock caused by layoffs and help keep skilled workers in their communities. Benefits come from Oregon employers’ payroll taxes, not workers’ paychecks. Learn more at <a href="https://unemployment.oregon.gov/">unemployment.oregon.gov</a>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>About Paid</strong><strong> Leave Oregon</strong></p>

<p>Paid Leave Oregon provides temporary, paid time away from work so employees can have financial security when experiencing significant life events. Covered events include welcoming a new child, recovering from a serious health condition, caring for a family member with a serious health condition, or addressing issues related to sexual assault, domestic violence, stalking, or harassment. Paid leave benefits help Oregonians stay connected to their jobs and maintain financial stability during these major personal events. Learn more at <a href="https://paidleave.oregon.gov/">paidleave.orogon.gov</a>.</p>

<hr />
<p>The Oregon Employment Department (OED) is an equal opportunity agency. OED provides free help so you can use our services. Some examples are sign language and spoken language interpreters, written materials in other languages, large print, audio, and other formats. To get help, please call 503-947-1444. TTY users call 711. You can also send an email to <a href="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov">communications@employ.oregon.gov</a>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>El Departamento de Empleo de Oregon (OED) es una agencia de igualdad de oportunidades. El OED proporciona ayuda gratuita para que usted pueda utilizar nuestros servicios. Algunos ejemplos son intérpretes de lengua de señas e idiomas hablados, materiales escritos en otros idiomas, letra grande, audio y otros formatos. Para obtener ayuda, por favor llame al 503-947-1444. Usuarios de TTY pueden llamar al 711. También puede enviar un correo electrónico a <a href="mailto:communications@employ.oregon.gov">communications@employ.oregon.gov</a>.</p>

headline: Early morning residential structure fire leaves family and pets displaced (Photo)
detail:
<p>At 11:46pm, November 17<sup>th</sup>, Bend Fire and Rescue crews were dispatched to a structure fire at a single family home behind Three Sisters Adventist Christian School, off of Tumalo road. The resident reported being woken up to what sounded like a “hail storm.” She didn’t notice any fire inside the home but&nbsp;<span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif">when she went outside, she</span> found flames coming from under the eaves and roof, near the stovepipe of the woodstove. <span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif">Due to the absence of smoke in the home at that time, smoke alarms did not go off.&nbsp;</span>Because of their quick actions, all 5 residents, including three children and multiple pets, were able to exit the manufactured home safely.&nbsp; The fire was ignited from the radiant heat of the woodstove pipe that was too close to the wooden facia board of the eaves. The woodstove pipe melted the vinyl rain gutter and ignited the eaves, which spread to the attic. The fire was contained and did not spread to the interior of the home, however, the water and roof damage makes the home unihabitable. <span style="font-family:arial,sans-serif">&nbsp;</span>Building loss is estimated at $65,000 and content loss estimated at $25,000.</p>

<p>We want to remind residents that having a home fire escape plan can be crucial in being able to escape quickly and safely from a house fire. Always have a plan for your family and pets. For help information in creating, practicing and implementing a home fire escape plan with your family, please call Bend Fire &amp; Rescue.</p>
